entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the operational semantics of `OP_CODESEPARATOR` in blockchain scripting contexts. It is pointed out that a more precise implementation would involve signing the position of the last executed `OP_CODESEPARATOR`. This approach is considered superior and aligns with thoughtful considerations on how to effectively manage script execution processes. Nevertheless, there's an acknowledgment regarding the continuous support for `OP_CODESEPARATOR` within legacy Pay-to-Script-Hash (P2SH) scripts, suggesting a preference to maintain the existing implementation to avoid disruptions.
The conversation also touches upon the broader implications of modifying Script, the scripting language used for Bitcoin and similar cryptocurrencies. There's an apparent concern about the complexity introduced by adding more flag combinations and the potential risks to consensus code stability. The idea of creating new versions of Script by copying and pasting code rather than amending existing scripts is floated as a strategy to preserve legacy behavior without compromising the integrity of consensus changes.
This exchange underscores the delicate balance between innovation and compatibility within cryptocurrency scripting. Maintaining legacy support while exploring more efficient or effective implementations presents challenges, notably in ensuring that changes do not inadvertently alter consensus mechanisms. The dialogue further illustrates the technical and philosophical hurdles faced by developers navigating the evolution of blockchain technologies.
